div.p: ANTONIO: We make lots of choices every day like... What to wear, how to spend our money or what to eat...
ANTONIO: And we don't make these choices in a vacuum; they're influenced by the things going on in our lives... such as wanting to stay healthy.
ANTONIO: Every decision we make is influenced by psychological influences like our attitudes, beliefs, values, preferences and our personalities.
ANTONIO: When it comes to heart disease, these might be attitudes like... "Exercising is a total waste of time." Or...
ANTONIO: "I'm not big on vegetables. They just don't fill me up."
ANTONIO: Social factors also play a role. Friends, family, media and social norms all influence our choices.
ANTONIO: There was a time when eating healthy food and exercising before breakfast made you a weird "health nut."
ANTONIO: That attitude didn't exactly encourage people to take care of themselves.
ANTONIO: Today things are different. People want to be seen as physically fit. And that's because social norms have changed.
ANTONIO: So psychological and social factors can influence our choices, but they don't cause or prevent the health problem.
ANTONIO: Any of us can reduce our own risk, and make low-risk choices regardless of our personality or social group.
ANTONIO: Now, it's time to test your understanding of the concepts we've just learned. Watch this video clip; there will be a few questions about it afterwards.
NARRATOR: Meet Joe. Joe means well, but he doesn't always eat healthy food.
NARRATOR: Greasy takeout last night, pizza today— Joe's usually up late, surfing the web with the help of a case of cola and a bag—or two—of chips.
NARRATOR: In fact, just about the only time Joe and his friends get their heart rate up is during an especially competitive video game.
